Title: LES: By Students, for Faculty: A Rapid Brightspace Implementation
Description: In early 2023 we were given the mandate to rapidly transition to Brightspace. We developed an innovative plan to deliver quality course content very quickly to our faculty. This presentation will share the steps we took to organize, implement, and successfully transition to Brightspace using a diverse pool of local and international student workers.
Topics: LMS Site Admin and IT Effectiveness

Title: LES: Crafting Inclusive Online Learning: UDL and Brightspace for Educators
Description: In the fast-paced world of online education, creating inclusive learning environments that cater to the needs of every learner is paramount. Join us for an exciting dive into the fusion of universal design for learning (UDL) principles with the Brightspace learning management system (LMS) your ticket to revolutionizing online content creation. By leveraging the inherent adaptability and versatility of Brightspace, educators will get hands-on practical tips on making learning flexible, accessible and equitable. From personalizing learning adventures to crafting content that speaks to every learning style, this session is all about making your online courses more engaging and accessible.

Title: LES: Integrating Mental Wellness Education Into Ongoing Curriculum
Description: Educators' plates to teach the core curriculum they are responsible for is already overflowing yet they are continually asked to add more. A deep caring for students and a push for more trauma-informed practices warrants turn-key options to help educators reach their students while continuing to deliver course content. Such an option exists and is proving to be effective in creating meaningful conversations about mental health, aiding students reach out for help as needed and encouraging an atmosphere of respect within the classroom. A Living Curriculum: Stories of Life Through Darkness will be presented. Attendees will have the opportunity of viewing and interacting with the program.
Speakers:
Linda Poulin
The Robb Nash Project

Steve Smith
The Robb Nash Project

Title: LES: Making Designer Choices: How to Bridge Practice and Pedagogy
Description: This session will explore the intersection of instructional design and instructor training. By exploring how instructional designers craft immersive learning experiences within their own classes, we can uncover valuable insights for instructor training methodologies. Through survey results and practical examples, attendees will gain actionable strategies to elevate teaching and learning experiences within their institutions. Whether you're an instructional designer, instructor or administrator, this session will help identify and explore the transformative potential of merging pedagogy with practice in the realm of instructor training.

Title: LES: One Size Doesn't Fit All
Description: Unlocking the full potential of education means prioritizing and recognizing the diverse needs of learners. We know individuals absorb information in unique ways and acknowledging and addressing these distinct learning requirements is paramount. To champion learner's needs, we chose to embark on a journey toward creating an educational environment that nurtures growth and confidence.

Title: LES: Shifting Perspectives: Embracing Process-Centric Learning Models and Assessments
Description: Dive into two use cases that utilize elements of personalized learning, stakeholder engagement and inclusive decision-making in building bespoke learning and l/earner assessment worlds. Explore forms of l/earner partnerships, discuss prioritizing diverse perspectives and foster transparency throughout the process. Explore steps towards building equitable paths toward professional realization.

Title: LES: Using PostMan for Bulk Changes in Brightspace!
Description:
Brightspace is a fantastic system with many options to make mass changes; however, methods like REST API calls can be intimidating! We have found an extremely useful and reliable method to leverage PostMan to make these bulk changes with easy an easy-to-follow guide on how we tackle a major impact event every semester, Course Activations. While some institutions may not need to leverage a tool in this way, Dallas College uses PostMan to provide students "early access" to roughly 13,000 courses each term using this semi-automated process. Courses are opened the Wednesday prior to the official start date in order to provide students extra time to review syllabi, view their digital textbook, and browse through available content and activities. Additionally, course end dates are managed through PostMan to allow students additional time to check their grades and/or complete any late work allowed by their instructors. The best part is that this is well within the free use of the PostMan tool!

Take a journey with the Dallas College LMS System Admins and let us show you the magic and fun of using PostMan to save time, headaches, and your sanity!
Topics: LMS Site Admin and IT Effectiveness

Title: LES: Using Rubrics in Your Course for Consistent and Standardized Grading
Description: Are your students asking lots of questions about assignments and how they are graded? “Why did I get that grade?” Providing a rubric to help answer students’ questions about how assignments will be graded before they submit an assignment will help answer those questions for you. Rubrics can help standardize grading and create a more consistent way to grade assignments and discussions. Come join this session and see how rubrics can help you.

Title: LES: When Practical Meets Lofty: Leveraging Professional Development Workshops to Positively Increase Learning Outcomes
Description: An interactive session in which the facilitators aim to demonstrate how two of their workshop formats can be leveraged in order to increase educator learning outcomes. The session is part presentation of the real-world context of these two workshops and the team that coordinates them and part collaborative conversation with attendees how the concepts presented might be leveraged at their institutions.

Description: Brightspace includes excellent “View As” functionality allowing instructors to see the Learner perspective of their courses. However, “View As” does not provide an accurate representation of some Brightspace tools and functions. Purdue built a true Demo Student that can be added by any instructor to any course. This session will demonstrate the benefits of a true Learner experience, discuss how Purdue built this tool and demonstrate its use.

In this session, we will show you how our learning technologies ecosystem map has changed, how we manage the increasing number of third-party tools and how we keep our teaching community informed. Finally, we will also share some best practices and success stories.

Title: LES: Are You Tired of Wading Through Known Issues?
Description: Are you tired of wading through endless rows of known issues in multiple documents? Have you spent hours upon hours comparing your reported issues with D2L's published known issues? Is your list so long that people don't want to look at it?

Title: LES: Development Tiers: How to Provide Flexible, Standardized Course Development That Satisfies Organizational Demand and Motivates Course Developers
Description: The demand for course development can be burdensome within the higher education environment that utilizes a centralized model of course development. How can academic leadership approach development projects in a way that can both meet organizational demand and enable a high degree of satisfaction for course development teams? The answer: Development Tiers.

Title: LES: Enhancing Online Education: The Faculty Engagement Dashboard and Regular Substantive Interaction (RSI)
Description: Ensuring faculty engagement is crucial for student success and a fundamental requirement for online education, notably through Regular Substantive Interaction (RSI). RSI entails continuous and meaningful engagement between students and instructors in online courses, emphasizing teaching, learning, and assessment. At Pima Community College (PCC), our commitment to student success and enhancing RSI is exemplified by the introduction of a faculty engagement dashboard. Developed in collaboration with data analytics consultants from GCOM and ASR, this innovative tool provides a real-time, prioritized view of online courses in need of attention, based on key engagement metrics such as faculty course access, announcement frequency, grading timeliness, and depth of feedback to students.

Michael Slattery

Title: LES: Macro, Micro and Back Again: Flexibility Through Structure With an Instructional Technology Management Cycle

Our instructional technology management cycle documents routine tasks foreseeing major projects and visualizing processes for clarity. This macro perspective ensures micro tasks align, optimizing tech usage while supporting users and helping the tech managers stay flexible and adapt to challenges ensuring seamless operations.

Title: LES: Maximizing Brightspace: Transformative Strategies for Engaging Learners From Day One to Graduation!
Description: Are you fully tapping into Brightspace's potential to ignite student engagement and foster academic success? Join us as we dive deep into innovative approaches to leverage Brightspace as more than just a content delivery platform. Discover how to captivate and inspire learners even before the first day of classes, and sustain their motivation throughout their academic journey. In this session, participants will embark on a journey to reimagine Brightspace as a dynamic online hub for building vibrant academic communities. We'll explore strategies for fostering mentorship, nurturing student success, and promoting equitable degree attainment in higher education. From identifying key student audience groups to outlining community needs and crafting intentional support systems, this session will equip you with actionable ideas and the compelling "why" behind them. Leave with tools and insights to transform your approach to online learning and take student success to new heights.

Dolly Rosenbrook

Title: LES: Mind The Gap: Diagnostic Assessments to Feed Forward Learning
Description: The topic of diagnostic/baseline assessments is relevant to “competency-based learning” as we need to address where students have been and where they are at with their skill sets, competency and knowledge to ensure they are ready and able to access the curricula in their various courses. The session will begin with a presentation of various issues that have come to light in the Faculty of Computer Science at Dalhousie University, how diagnostic/baseline assessments informed instructors and students of learning gaps, and what types of interventions have been used in course delivery to facilitate student success. Participants will have an opportunity to discuss issues from their contexts and brainstorm takeaway ideas for implementation in Brightspace.

Title: LES: Using Analytics to Create Better Courses Through Survey Results
Description: Surveys can feel like a requirement rather than a key part of course development. Yet they give valuable insights into your students. The results can be combined with other metrics to give you an even fuller picture and help identify ways to improve your courses now. You can store data for future analysis, even if you aren't ready to take that step right now. Jump into the world of survey data, and learn to love this tool.

Title: Using Brightspace’s Insights Report Builder for a Data-driven Approach in to Support Student Success

In this presentation, we will discuss how Temasek Polytechnic, Singapore navigated this challenge by employing Brightspace’s Insights Report Builder. This tool facilitates data preparation and the creation of visualized reports on student quiz performance, featuring section-based filtering. These reports are integrated directly into the course homepage, enabling educators to implement precise teaching interventions. 

Building on this experience, we developed a comprehensive dashboard that includes detailed views of individual student quiz results, progress tracking through LMS content, reminders of upcoming assignment deadlines, and an analysis of students perceived versus actual performance in subjects. This enriched dataset empowers educators to conduct data-driven discussions with students, effectively guiding them towards achieving their academic potential. The utilization of LMS data for these enhancements underscores the system's significant role in boosting student support and educational outcomes, showcasing the potential in enriching the teaching and learning experience.

Title: Become a D2L Copyright Ninja
Description:
Faculty, designers, and admins often have little guidance for using copyrighted materials for teaching. This interactive crash-course session from the author of "Training Your Faculty About Copyright When the Lawyer Isn't Looking" offers use-them-tomorrow lessons to keep educators in the US, Canada and worldwide on the "good side" of copyright law. This crash-course session is based on recent research that aims to create a set of rule-of-thumb guidelines for faculty and developers (Tobin, 2014) to help them to navigate confidently when selecting and using materials for their courses. This session promises a simplified yet deep understanding of how to work with materials created by others in an ethical fashion, so that participants will stay "on the good side of the law" the majority of the time. The session is aimed at faculty members, designers and administrators in colleges and universities in the United States (17 US Code § 107), Canada (Canada Code RSC C 42.29) and worldwide (WIPO Convention). Participants who design online content that supports interactions with learners will benefit especially from this session. The session aims not only to teach the core concepts of copyright but is also a train-the-trainer session designed to give participants the ideas and tools to be able to be "copyright ninjas" when they return to their institutions. Participants should come prepared to be part of the conversation. Based on real-life examples from session participants and recent court cases (e.g., Decherney, 2013; Keengew & Georgina, 2013 Band, 2012) we will answer some core questions about copyright for online design and teaching: 

  • What is a copy? 
  • What is and isn't copyrighted? 
  • Fair use and fair dealing criteria (PANE +CA) 
  • Creative commons and other special-rights licenses 
  • Seeking permission beyond fair use 
  • When copyright doesn't even apply 

Participants will learn how to use copyrighted materials for online teaching purposes, as well as how to work around copyright by using permissions, licenses, copyright-free resources and alternative-access methods. 

Disclaimer: This session is an overview of various models and methods regarding copyrighted content and ownership of intellectual property. The facilitator is not a legal professional, and no part of this session is intended to constitute legal advice.

You’ll learn how Walmart Canada:   

  • decided to build their own talent pipeline when hiring wasn't cutting it   
  • used skill mapping data to build career pathways that addressed major business needs   
  • started enrolling in learning opportunities that are changing their lives—and filling Walmart’s skills gaps at the same time
Topics: Accessibility and Inclusive Learning, Change Management, Faculty and Trainer Development, Future of Work/Education, Upskilling/Reskilling

Title: Leveraging Brightspace’s Learning Outcomes Tool to Capture Learner Achievement Levels from Across Multiple Course Offerings Into One Mastery View
Description: Join us for an exploration on how our organisation used an innovative approach to design an interactive practical legal training program using Brightspace. Delve into how we creatively customised and harnessed the potential of Brightspace Learning Outcomes tool to track and measure learner achievement levels from across multiple course offerings into the one Mastery View. This presentation will look at the reasons behind our choice to use the Learning Outcomes tool, the challenges we faced along the way, and the innovative solutions we crafted to overcome them to meet our vision.
Topics: D2L Solutions How To's/Tips and Tricks

Title: DEI: Dialogue and Action
Description: In this session, D2L’s prestigious clients will discuss some effective practices that they leverage to foster DEI in their institutions. In today's diverse world, prioritizing DEI advances a sense of belonging among people and fosters driving innovation and performance. Drawing on real-life examples, this session will address key topics such as inclusivity, equity and allyship and explore actionable strategies for cultivating a more inclusive culture.
Audience: Association & Training Organizations, Corporate Learning, Higher Education, K-12

Title: The AI Insurgence: Battlefield Academia
Description: Copyleaks completed a year-long study that analyzed trends in AI adoption and plagiarism detection among tens of thousands of college and high school students globally from January 2023 to January 2024. The findings indicate a significant 76% rise in AI-generated content and a 51% decrease in plagiarism rates, highlighting the evolving academic landscape and the need for comprehensive solutions to ensure educational integrity and prevent the stifling of creativity, original thought, and critical thinking. Join Shouvik Paul, chief operating officer of Copyleaks, as he guides educators, administrators, and EdTech leaders through how they can move forward in the age of AI, address AI-based plagiarism, and learn to adopt genAI responsibly in workflows and in the classroom to supplement the learning journey while empowering originality and upholding integrity.

Title: FIVE MINUTE FLARE: Going Viral: The Memefication of Student Communication
Description: An email is sent, an announcement is posted, information is seemingly available, and yet people still don’t know about this important thing you’ve tried to inform them about. How do we not only get users to read important updates but just notice the information in the first place? [Insert Funny Cat GIF here]. Taking strategies of internet virality, we’ve determined a quite effective method of communication with students: funny memes and GIFs.

Title: FIVE MINUTE FLARE: From PJs to Productivity
Description: Since the pandemic, the rise of remote work has changed our health and wellness needs. While working in pajamas was initially intriguing, the long-term impact can pose a threat to our physical and mental well-being. We will dive into tips for physical, mental, emotional and environmental stability, encouraging you to thrive in your workplace. Whether you are clocking in from your home office or your work office, you will discover tools to cultivate a healthy work-life balance regardless of your work location.

Title: FIVE MINUTE FLARE: Ultimate Medical Academy (UMA) Curriculum Team’s Award-Winning Journey: A Story of Change Management, Performance and Engagement
Description: In Fall 2023, the Curriculum team at Ultimate Medical Academy (UMA) received an excellence award for their outstanding work. This was the first time in over a decade that the team achieved this recognition. How did they do it? In this presentation, you will learn about the change management process that the team followed for three years. You will also discover the tools and strategies that they used to improve their performance and engagement. Join us to hear the inspiring story of the UMA Curriculum team and their journey to excellence.

Title: A Bright IDEA: Using Brightspace to Enhance Inclusion, Diversity, Equity and Accessibility in K-12
Description: Inclusion, diversity, equity and accessibility (IDEA) are cornerstones of modern society. Governments, corporations and organizations are embracing these principles. These concepts are especially important across the education sector. But how do these ideals become embedded into daily teaching practice? Online educators face particular challenges in ensuring IDEA practices are incorporated into their K-12 online classrooms. Participants will leave the session with a take-home “BrightIDEA” ToolKit designed by Dr. Chisholm. The toolkit is aimed to support online K-12 teachers who want to create inclusive and accessible online K-12 classrooms in Brightspace.

Title: Begin with a Strong Backbone: Building More Sustainable, Shareable Brightspace Courses
Description: Online courses are frequently copied, reused and shared—a process that allows courses to grow and change, hopefully for the better. But all too often, online courses begin to break down as they are rolled over and passed between multiple instructors. In this session, we'll explore ways in which to use Brightspace to design and build online courses with a strong backbone, or foundation, so that they may be copied, reused, shared, inherited and updated without losing their structure, usability and effectiveness.

Title: Transforming Course Compliance: How Conestoga's Essential Elements Scanner Skyrocketed Quality and Consistency
Description: Discover how Conestoga College boosted adherence to their essential elements’ requirements to more than 80%. This innovative real-time scanning tool checks the course structure, provides completion status and actionable feedback for instructors on incomplete items. Join the team as they highlight the solutions and walk you through their challenges, lessoned learned, and how this work was a catalyst for diving deep into Brightspace API.

Title: Unlocking the Power of Social Learning: Enhancing Educational Quality with FeedbackFruits
Description: Discover the transformative potential of social learning dynamics with FeedbackFruits! Join our engaging exploration into the realm of group learning experiences within higher education. Start by redefining Group Formation with customized strategies that empower educators to strategically structure student cohorts based on specific pedagogical objectives. This innovative approach challenges traditional LMS group allocation, setting the stage for interactive group engagement through social annotation, video discussions, and collaborative assessments. Transition seamlessly into Team-Based Learning Activities, guiding students through a journey from individual assessments to dynamic group debates that foster enhanced comprehension and critical thinking skills. Dive into Peer Review, where participants provide constructive feedback on peers' work, enriching the learning cycle. By integrating ongoing team assessment throughout the course, students develop effective feedback skills while providing educators with valuable insights to refine teaching methodologies and personalize group dynamics. Join us in redefining quality teaching through the implementation of our innovative social learning solutions.

Title: FIVE MINUTE FLARE: Early Identification Intervention Support System
Description: The Early Identification Intervention Support System (EIISS) is designed to identify students early who are struggling academically and provide timely supports to improve student success (including retention) in first year by using proactive measures. We aim to scale this system across the institution and build it to be holistic on both the front-end and at the point of intervention by integrating connections to campus services/resources. By using a simplified statistical approach to reviewing students grades at the correct time during the semester (that means no AI … no, I’m not kidding), we identify at-risk students and connect them with campus services.

Title: FIVE MINUTE FLARE: Creating Successful Business Partnerships
Description: Attendees will explore the essential elements of building and maintaining a strong working relationship between two companies. Drawing on best practices and real-world examples, attendees will gain insights into effective communication, collaboration and conflict resolution strategies that can enhance the success of their partnerships.
Speakers:
John Nimick
D2L

Zachary Friedman
University of Maryland Global Campus

Title: "D2L Ate My Homework", or "CSI: D2L": Academic Integrity Beyond (and Besides) AI
Description: "The dog ate my homework" is likely the most common, though arguably the least effective, excuse used by students who do not submit their work on time. In the time of online and hybrid teaching, homework-loving pets are a thing of the past, and the LMS has become the new scapegoat. Like an episode of CSI, in this session, we will look at real-life examples of (anonymous) students creatively attempting to blame D2L to get away with a missed deadline—from doctored screenshots to fabricated alibis—and I will share tips for uncovering the truth besides quizzes and assignment logs. Remember to bring your detective hat.
Topics: D2L Solutions How To's/Tips and Tricks

Title: 54 Campuses – 1 Shared Brightspace Site: SUNY’s New Digital Learning Environment
Description: The State University of New York (SUNY) has embarked on a project that will change the landscape of online learning across the SUNY system. Nearly complete with their multi-year project, SUNY’s Digital Learning Environment (DLE) has taken 54 campuses (plus 3 additional SUNY Institutions) and has transitioned them from disparate LMS systems into a single shared multi-tenant Brightspace environment. After providing some project context, the curtains will be pulled back to show the primary thoughts and structure behind what has become the SUNY DLE environment.
Topics: LMS Site Admin and IT Effectiveness

Title: An Assessment-First Approach for Non-Degree Credentials
Description: Education and the world of work are increasingly shifting toward skills-based models built upon competency frameworks and demonstration of mastery for learning, hiring and advancement. At Education Design Lab, we’re leveraging Brightspace to enable an innovative assessment-first approach to skills validation and development, which leads to the award of digital micro-credentials. Upon enrollment, our learners are presented with simulation-based assessment opportunities to demonstrate their skills and are directed to relevant learning content only if a skills gap is identified. Come see our approach in action and learn how we’re taking advantage of Brightspace’s robust competencies, awards and release conditions to empower our learners with validated skills and credentials.
Speakers:
Nishita Chheda
Education Design Lab

Tara Laughlin
Education Design Lab

Title: Creating an Engaging Learning Environment Using Brightspace Tools
Description: This session will explore various workflows and Brightspace tools you can utilize to create an engaging learning environment for your learners including: video note, gamification tools and multi-media artifacts.
Topics: D2L Brightspace Training, D2L Solutions How To's/Tips and Tricks, Learner Engagement
Audience: Association & Training Organizations, Corporate Learning, Higher Education, K-12

Title: Desire to Indigenize: Transforming Brightspace Into Sacred Space—Learning from a Blackfoot Odyssey
Description: Oki! (a Blackfoot greeting) We will show how Brightspace can be used to transport learners to a ceremonial space. Attendees will bear witness to our new, exclusive short film, Sunbonnet Lodge Tipi Design, based on last year’s D2L Fusion presentation, as well as learn about our latest work on the sacredness of land inspired by a Blackfoot Odyssey—in literature and in real life.
Speakers:
Christopher Grignard
Mount Royal University

Joe (Iitsooahp’potah) Eagle Tail Feathers
Sundance Coulee Society

Title: Dipping Our Toe Into the Data Lake and Performance+
Description: There is growing interest in data and analytics at Waterloo. Some areas of interest include student engagement, student success, instructional design and accreditation. For a variety of reasons, little has been done with Brightspace data in the past. Some challenges include data governance, privacy, access to data, resources and capacity. Waterloo is piloting Performance+ and evaluating whether it will meet our needs, or if we need our own data lake with Brightspace data, or if we need a combined approach. Come to engage in a discussion about how Waterloo is approaching data and analytics and approaches used by your institution.
Speakers:
Daspina Fefekos
University of Waterloo

Scott Anderson
University of Waterloo

Sean Warrren
University of Waterloo

Stephen Tosh
University of Waterloo

Title: Working Smarter: A System-Level View of Bulk Process Management
Description: This session is geared towards site administrators, we will present an overview of how bulk processing is most commonly used to suit the needs of the various University System of Georgia institutions. We will recommend ways to avoid common mistakes, streamline redundant tasks and reduce manual errors. The session is ideal for those who wish to leverage existing tools to "work smarter” or who may not have the resources to develop custom solutions. The discussion will include examples for BCC, CCB, IPSIS copy content and the best ways to combine the tools. We will also cover managing content at the source level, purging data and Bulk User Management.
Topics: D2L Solutions How To's/Tips and Tricks
Speakers:
Marla Wilks
University System of Georgia

Wendy Grisham
University System of Georgia

Title: Intelligent Uses of Artificial Intelligence in Education and Training
Description: Each of the three panelists bring a unique perspective to the discussion of potential uses of Artificial Intelligence in education and training. They will share some of the effective uses that they've experienced as well as some of the potential uses that you might want to steer clear of. Some topics will include AI uses for student role-play, e-learning content creation, and encouraging transparency in student uses of AI, and more!
Speakers:
Anthony Nappi
Lastinger Center for Learning

Lindsay Shipman
D2L Corporation

Reed Dickson
Pima Community College

Rhonelee Soria
Los Angeles Pacific University

Title: Costs or Catalysts: Unlocking Potential Together
Description:
In today's fast-paced world, developing talent is more important than ever. This is a dynamic talk that challenges traditional methods of talent development and offers fresh, innovative approaches to uncover hidden potential within your workforce. We'll focus on range of talent from often-overlooked hourly workers to leadership and show how investing in their growth can lead to big wins for your organization and the community. 

Join Disney veteran Chris Trout who will help you discover the hidden power within your entire workforce. This includes: 

  • Cultivating new skills: Learn actionable strategies to empower employees at every level, from hourly workers to leadership. 
  • Investing in often-overlooked talent: Discover how developing hourly employees can unlock significant organizational and community benefits. 
  • Shifting your perspective: Move beyond seeing employees as costs or productivity metrics. Recognize them as vital contributors capable of fueling business success. 

Chris, with decades of experience leading innovative initiatives at Disney and top brands, will share: 

  • Real-world success stories: See how programs like Disney Aspire empower employees and drive results. 
  • Actionable insights: Leave with a clear plan to rethink your talent development approach. 
  • Interactive activities: Engage in thought-provoking exercises designed to inspire change. 

This engaging session will transform how you view talent and potential within.
Topics: Change Management, Future of Work/Education, Upskilling/Reskilling, Leadership and Organizational Strategy

Title: Enhancing Education: Turnitin's Upcoming Innovations
Description: Education has undergone significant changes over the past few years, and Turnitin is adapting to better serve educators. Join us to discover the latest additions to our product roadmap and learn how these innovations can help institutions promote a culture of academic integrity and significantly improve grading and feedback for instructors and students. In this session, we'll discuss our latest AI detection advancements, delve into our enhanced similarity report, and demo our redesigned feedback and grading experience. Plus, get an exclusive sneak peek at our forthcoming student writing tool currently in development. Don't miss out on this informative session. We hope to see you there.

Title: FEATURED BREAKOUT: Enhancing Learning Using Learning Analytics: The ALeRT Approach at Temasek Polytechnic
Description: In the rapidly evolving educational landscape, harnessing the power of data to inform teaching and learning is crucial. Learning analytics provides educators with valuable insights into student learning and helps them to make timely data-driven decisions to improve educational outcomes. This presentation delves into the use of a learning analytics approach for responsive teaching at Temasek Polytechnic, Singapore. Known as ALeRT (Assessing Learning in Real Time), this learning analytics approach is grounded in the educational principles of Diagnostic and Formative Assessments and demonstrates versatility across both K-12 and Higher Education settings. The presentation also highlights how educators can leverage Brightspace’s quiz features to gather insightful data to diagnose students’ learning, identify students’ learning gaps in real-time through Brightspace’s built-in visualisation features, and the implications on bridging the learning gaps to close the feedback loop by educators.

Title: Lessons from the Field: How AI Tools Can Support Teaching & Learning
Description:
Ready to unlock the potential of AI in your teaching? This session dives headfirst into the real-world experiences of educators who are already leveraging AI tools to transform student learning.
Join us for a 45-minute panel discussion where you'll:
 
Hear from educators who are using AI for personalized learning, formative assessment, differentiated instruction and more.
Discover practical examples of how AI can be implemented across various subjects and contexts.
Gain insights into the challenges and rewards of integrating AI tools into your teaching practice.
Speakers:
Dr. Jess Zeitler
UCATT at University of Arizona

Title: Outcomes Achievement Dashboard and Course Outcomes
Description: The new Outcomes Achievement Dashboard provides aggregate achievements across courses at the parent outcome level for program admins based on the new achievement threshold. This new dashboard is being released in July along with some new Course Outcomes achievement visualization for instructors in Mastery View.
Topics: Change Management, D2L Solutions How To's/Tips and Tricks, Data and Analytics, Instructional Technology and Design

Title: Tech-Enhanced Learning in the K-12 Classroom With Brightspace
Description: This session focuses on creating a tech-enhanced learning environment with Brightspace that supports differentiated instruction in the brick & mortar classroom. Participants are invited to learn how tools like Portfolio can not only enhance student engagement but support best practices in Assessment & Evaluation. We will also explore ways to save teachers time through the application of release conditions, intelligent agents, and the groups tool to support differentiated instruction. Recognizing that teaching in the face-to-face classroom means finding new ways to engage learners, we invite the audience to re-imagine content delivery with the use of highly interactive and engaging materials authored with Creator+, as well as using awards and badges to provide students with positive reinforcement.
Topics: Accessibility and Inclusive Learning, Blended Learning or Hy-Flex, Learner Engagement, Personalized Learning

Title: To Build or Not to Build: Supporting Implementation through Custom Development
Description: In the ever-evolving landscape of education technology and innovation, the question of whether to build or not to build custom solutions remains a pivotal dilemma for many organizations. This presentation delves into how Missouri State University has developed custom applications utilizing the Brightspace APIs to support implementation across our campuses. This approach has allowed us to empower our faculty while reducing security concerns and learning curve for users as we transition systems. Tools created include a sandbox and source course request page, add users functionality, and bulk user management tools for individual communities. This case study underscores the importance of understanding the unique challenges and opportunities within one's institution and illustrates that, with the right strategy and resources, building custom solutions can profoundly impact the educational experience.
Speakers:
Ethan Lynch
Missouri State University

Krista Lair
Missouri State University (West Plains Campus)

Lacey Geiger
Missouri State University

Title: Understanding Approaches to Digital Accessibility in Academic Programming
Description: This session introduces approaches to digital accessibility in higher education specific to practices applicable to academic programming using learning management systems. The session provides a high-level view of how a digital accessibility conceptual framework and toolkit affects the adoption of Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) through a centralized approach to building a culture of accessibility through a top-down, bottom-up campus-wide initiative.
Speakers:
Angela Jackson
University of South Dakota

Eric Mosterd
University of South Dakota / South Dakota Board of Regents
